domains.name: Requirements Definition
domains.description: Artifacts and rules that specify what the Product must do, under which conditions, and how requirements are structured, validated, and traced before design and implementation.

terms.name: Product Backlog
terms.definition: A structured and ordered list of all planned Product work, including Epics, Features, and User Stories.
terms.description: Serves as the single ordered source of work items, enabling prioritization, sequencing, and controlled scope management across delivery.

terms.name: Backlog Item
terms.definition: An individual work element within the Product Backlog, such as an Epic, Feature, or User Story.
terms.description: Defines the atomic unit stored in the backlog structure, enabling uniform handling of hierarchy, prioritization, and tracking.

terms.name: Backlog Structure
terms.definition: The hierarchical organization of the Product Backlog into Epics, Features, and User Stories.
terms.description: Defines how work is decomposed and related across levels, enabling consistent slicing from large deliverables to implementable units.

terms.name: Backlog Consistency
terms.definition: The alignment of Backlog Items with Product Vision, Epics, Strategic Product Scope, and Business Goals to ensure coherent direction.
terms.description: Ensures backlog content does not contradict strategic intent and prevents drift by validating alignment across hierarchy and priorities.

terms.name: Capability Requirements
terms.definition: High-level requirement statements describing what each Capability Area must support, bridging strategic scope and detailed requirements.
terms.description: Defines expectations at the capability level to guide consistent decomposition into feature and story requirements.

terms.name: Feature Requirements
terms.definition: Structured requirement statements describing expected system behavior for each Feature, positioned between capability requirements and user stories.
terms.description: Clarifies what a feature must achieve before writing detailed stories, reducing ambiguity and improving completeness.

terms.name: Functional Requirement
terms.definition: A precise description of what the system must do, defining behaviors, actions, or operations required to support User Stories and Features.
terms.description: Specifies required behaviors in an implementable form, enabling design, development, and testing to agree on expected system output.

terms.name: Non-Functional Requirement
terms.definition: A constraint or quality attribute defining how the system must operate, such as performance, security, reliability, or usability.
terms.description: Defines quality expectations and operational constraints that must be met across functionality, shaping architecture and acceptance decisions.

terms.name: Usability Requirements
terms.definition: Non-functional requirements describing how easily and effectively users must be able to interact with the system, expressed as measurable system qualities.
terms.description: Defines usability quality targets such as clarity and learnability without prescribing UI solutions, enabling verification through testing and reviews.

terms.name: Compliance Requirements
terms.definition: Non-functional requirements describing legal, regulatory, or industry-specific rules the Product must follow.
terms.description: Defines obligatory rules such as accessibility or data protection that constrain design, architecture, and operating procedures.

terms.name: Business Rules
terms.definition: Explicit rules that govern system behavior, constraints, conditions, or allowed actions in specific contexts.
terms.description: Defines domain logic such as eligibility, pricing rules, validations, or decision policies that must be enforced consistently.

terms.name: User Story
terms.definition: A structured description of a user need or behavior expressed as a functional unit of work.
terms.description: Defines the smallest customer-value-driven work unit to implement, typically validated by acceptance criteria and readiness checks.

terms.name: System Logic
terms.definition: The internal rules, conditions, and processing steps the system uses to determine behavior under various scenarios.
terms.description: Describes how inputs, states, and rules produce outcomes, enabling consistent implementation across flows, edge cases, and error handling.

terms.name: Workflow
terms.definition: A defined sequence of steps describing how users or the system execute a process end-to-end, including alternative and exception paths.
terms.description: Defines an end-to-end process boundary and its paths, serving as a backbone for story mapping, requirements coverage, and later UX flows.

terms.name: Edge Case
terms.definition: A scenario that occurs at the extreme boundaries of expected use and reveals system behavior under rare or atypical conditions.
terms.description: Captures rare but plausible boundary conditions that must be handled safely and consistently to avoid defects and inconsistent behavior.

terms.name: Exception Scenario
terms.definition: A situation in which a process deviates from its standard path due to an error, missing input, or unexpected condition, describing the required system response.
terms.description: Defines what happens when the normal workflow cannot proceed, including system response, messaging, and recovery behavior.

terms.name: Story Mapping Structure
terms.definition: A structured representation of how Features and User Stories align along user workflows or activities to show the Product sliced into activities and supporting functionality.
terms.description: Organizes stories by user activity and progression to support prioritization, release slicing, and completeness validation across workflows.

terms.name: User Need Summary
terms.definition: A consolidated description of the underlying goals, motivations, and desired outcomes that each User Story aims to support.
terms.description: Provides the intent behind a story to keep implementation aligned with real user outcomes rather than literal interpretation of text.

terms.name: Acceptance Criteria
terms.definition: A structured set of conditions that define when a User Story is considered complete and correct.
terms.description: Defines verifiable conditions and expected outcomes that drive testing, review, and completion decisions for a story.

terms.name: Readiness Criteria
terms.definition: A defined set of conditions a User Story must meet before it can be implemented, ensuring clarity, completeness, and absence of ambiguity.
terms.description: Defines a quality gate for stories before implementation, reducing rework by ensuring required details and dependencies are resolved.

terms.name: Requirements Consistency
terms.definition: The alignment and coherence of all requirements, user stories, workflows, and logic so that they do not conflict or contradict each other.
terms.description: Ensures that requirements layers and process definitions do not produce contradictory behavior, preventing downstream design and build conflicts.

terms.name: Requirements Completeness Review
terms.definition: A structured evaluation confirming that all necessary requirements are present, fully expressed, and not missing critical cases or system rules.
terms.description: Checks whether the requirements set covers the needed behaviors, including edge and exception handling, and identifies omissions before design begins.

terms.name: Requirements Traceability Mapping
terms.definition: A structured mapping that links requirements across levels from capability to feature to user story to acceptance criteria to test cases.
terms.description: Creates explicit links for coverage control and impact analysis, ensuring that every requirement is implemented and verifiable.
